page.title: 19CORNISH HEDGES
page.content:
Cornish hedges surround many fields. They are made of granite stones with earth in between and turf on top. Ferns and flowering plants quickly transform the hedge into a bank. On the windward side there are mainly gorses and lichens, but the sheltered side is full of colour with primroses in April, Red Campion in May and June, and Foxglovs in July. Other prominent flowers include Cow Parsley, Blue Bells, Celandines and Herb Robert. Hawthorn, Hazel and holly are the commonest shrubs in the hedges.
Animals thrive in the shelter of the hedge. Butterflies and bees rest and feed on flowers, while digger wasps make nests in the earth. Other residents include pigmy shrews, bank voles, and wood mice, all food for local barn owls and buzzards.
